description: Explore fundamental philosophical questions about existence, knowledge, ethics, and the nature of reality through engaging lessons and thought experiments.

lessons.title: What is Philosophy?
lessons.description: Introduction to philosophical thinking and the branches of philosophy

sections.content: Philosophy is the love of wisdom. It's the systematic study of fundamental questions about existence, knowledge, values, reason, mind, and language. Unlike other disciplines that focus on specific aspects of reality, philosophy asks the big questions that underlie all human inquiry.

items: Metaphysics: The nature of reality and existence
Epistemology: The theory of knowledge
Ethics: Moral philosophy and values
Logic: The principles of valid reasoning
Aesthetics: Philosophy of art and beauty
Political Philosophy: Justice, rights, and government

sections.content: Philosophy doesn't just give you answers—it teaches you how to ask better questions and think critically about everything you encounter.

lessons.title: Ancient Greek Philosophy
lessons.description: Exploring the foundations laid by Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle

sections.content: Ancient Greece gave birth to systematic philosophical thinking. The trio of Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle established methods and questions that continue to influence philosophy today.

items: Socrates: The Socratic method and examined life
Plato: Theory of Forms and ideal state
Aristotle: Logic, virtue ethics, and empiricism
Pre-Socratics: Early theories about nature and reality

sections.content: The unexamined life is not worth living. - Socrates

lessons.title: Epistemology: What Can We Know?
lessons.description: Theories of knowledge, truth, and belief

sections.content: Epistemology asks fundamental questions: What is knowledge? How do we know what we know? Can we ever be certain of anything? These questions have profound implications for science, religion, and everyday life.

items: Justified true belief: The traditional definition of knowledge
Skepticism: Can we know anything with certainty?
Rationalism vs. Empiricism: Reason or experience?
The problem of induction: Can we trust patterns?
Gettier problems: Challenges to traditional definitions

sections.content: Knowledge traditionally requires three conditions: it must be true, you must believe it, and you must have justification for your belief.

lessons.title: Metaphysics: The Nature of Reality
lessons.description: Exploring existence, identity, time, and causation

sections.content: Metaphysics investigates the fundamental nature of reality. It asks questions about what exists, what it means to exist, and how different things relate to each other in the fabric of reality.

items: Ontology: What kinds of things exist?
Identity: What makes something the same over time?
Time: Is time real or an illusion?
Causation: How do causes produce effects?
Free will vs. Determinism: Are we truly free?
Mind-body problem: How does consciousness relate to physical matter?

sections.content: Ethics is the branch of philosophy concerned with questions of morality—how we ought to live, what makes actions right or wrong, and what constitutes a good life.

items: Consequentialism: Actions judged by outcomes (Utilitarianism)
Deontology: Actions judged by duties and rules (Kant)
Virtue Ethics: Focus on character and virtues (Aristotle)
Care Ethics: Emphasis on relationships and compassion
Moral Relativism: Are moral truths universal or cultural?

sections.content: Different ethical frameworks can lead to different conclusions about the same situation. Understanding multiple perspectives helps us make more thoughtful moral decisions.

lessons.title: Logic and Reasoning
lessons.description: Valid arguments, fallacies, and critical thinking

sections.content: Logic is the study of correct reasoning. It provides the foundation for all philosophical inquiry and helps us distinguish good arguments from bad ones.

items: Deductive reasoning: Arguments that guarantee their conclusions
Inductive reasoning: Arguments that support probable conclusions
Validity vs. Soundness: Structure vs. truth
Common fallacies: Recognizing flawed reasoning
Symbolic logic: Formal systems of reasoning

lessons.title: Modern and Contemporary Philosophy
lessons.description: From Descartes to present-day philosophical movements

sections.content: Modern philosophy began with a radical shift in how philosophers approached fundamental questions. Descartes' famous 'I think, therefore I am' marked the beginning of a new era focused on certainty and the nature of the self.

items: Rationalism: Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz
Empiricism: Locke, Berkeley, Hume
Kant's Critical Philosophy: Synthesis of rationalism and empiricism
Existentialism: Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Sartre, Camus
Phenomenology: Husserl, Heidegger, Merleau-Ponty
Analytic Philosophy: Russell, Wittgenstein, Quine

lessons.title: Political Philosophy
lessons.description: Justice, rights, and the ideal society

sections.content: Political philosophy examines fundamental questions about government, justice, rights, liberty, and political obligation. What makes a government legitimate? What rights do individuals have? How should society be organized?

items: Social Contract Theory: Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau
Theories of Justice: Rawls, Nozick, Sen
Liberty and Rights: Mill, Berlin
Democracy and its critics
Feminism and political philosophy
Global justice and cosmopolitanism

lessons.title: Philosophy of Mind and Consciousness
lessons.description: The mind-body problem and theories of consciousness

sections.content: How does physical matter give rise to subjective experience? This is one of philosophy's most challenging questions, sitting at the intersection of philosophy, neuroscience, and cognitive science.

items: Dualism: Mind and body are distinct substances
Physicalism: Everything is ultimately physical
Functionalism: Mental states defined by their functions
Property Dualism: One substance, two types of properties
Panpsychism: Consciousness is fundamental
The problem of qualia: Subjective experience

lessons.title: Philosophy Today and Practical Applications
lessons.description: Contemporary issues and applying philosophy to life

sections.content: Philosophy isn't just about abstract questions—it has practical applications in ethics, technology, science, and everyday life. Modern philosophers tackle contemporary challenges from AI ethics to climate change.

items: Bioethics: Medical decisions and biotechnology
Environmental ethics: Our obligations to nature
AI and technology ethics: Digital rights and responsibilities
Applied epistemology: Fake news and knowledge
Philosophy of science: Understanding scientific methods
Personal philosophy: Living an examined life

sections.content: Congratulations on completing Introduction to Philosophy! You now have the tools to think critically about fundamental questions and engage thoughtfully with complex ideas.
